text: <@UE1JQM9HQ> I finally finished your episode, and many of the things you mentioned resonated deeply! There was some overlap to our thinking, but I think you’ve definitely taken things further. Great interview <@U5TCAFTD3> !

elements.text: I finally finished your episode, and many of the things you mentioned resonated deeply! There was some overlap to our thinking, but I think you’ve definitely taken things further. Great interview

text: Thank you for listening to it. What did you like about it?

elements.text: Thank you for listening to it. What did you like about it?

text: <@UE1JQM9HQ> ok more specifically: I couldn’t agree more with the idea of a single render tree. It’s a huge undertaking and it was very brave of you and your team to go in that direction, but I think it’s ultimately worth it!

elements.text: ok more specifically: I couldn’t agree more with the idea of a single render tree. It’s a huge undertaking and it was very brave of you and your team to go in that direction, but I think it’s ultimately worth it!

text: I recently started writing a data inspector in Clojure and I felt really tired fighting with Swing and JavaFX and their Clojure wrappers, so I felt it was easier to attempt to just use Java2D to do everything. So same instinct as glamorous, a bit less clear in my mind but I’m already seeing my choice paying off (but it’s super buggy)

elements.text: I recently started writing a data inspector in Clojure and I felt really tired fighting with Swing and JavaFX and their Clojure wrappers, so I felt it was easier to attempt to just use Java2D to do everything. So same instinct as glamorous, a bit less clear in my mind but I’m already seeing my choice paying off (but it’s super buggy)

text: also, what you said about navigability of different data calling for different renderers fits pretty well with the new datafy/nav protocols in Clojure (still hugely under-utilized)

elements.text: also, what you said about navigability of different data calling for different renderers fits pretty well with the new datafy/nav protocols in Clojure (still hugely under-utilized)

text: Also the ad-hoc development tools idea is very interesting, especially because IDEs provide some “canned” queries on your system but in such a locked-in manner that it makes them marginally useless

elements.text: Also the ad-hoc development tools idea is very interesting, especially because IDEs provide some “canned” queries on your system but in such a locked-in manner that it makes them marginally useless

text:
<@UF5PAGQQ4> Indeed, the one-rendering-tree was both foolish and totally worth it :smile:. We can now express interfaces that are simply not possible otherwise. The interesting thing is that we do not yet know what we can do with the new found freedom.

For example, take a look at this: <https://twitter.com/feenkcom/status/1042163539950153728>

In this interface, the arrows go from inside the text editor to the other editors. You can actually also type in the editors and the arrows are added by the syntax highlighting live. This is possible because the text editor is made of elements and because the graph layouts can be expressed as regular layouts. This means that we can arbitrarily combine graphs-like interfaces (and graph structures are common place in software) with typical widgets.

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/feenkcom|@feenkcom>: One application of Connector is to help developers understand the code of connected examples. Now, it also makes it easy to understand how results are composed visually. Just flip the tile to get an inspector. #gtoolkit <https://pbs.twimg.com/tweet_video_thumb/DnaB8N3W4AAu2cu.jpg>

elements.text: Indeed, the one-rendering-tree was both foolish and totally worth it

. We can now express interfaces that are simply not possible otherwise. The interesting thing is that we do not yet know what we can do with the new found freedom.

For example, take a look at this:

In this interface, the arrows go from inside the text editor to the other editors. You can actually also type in the editors and the arrows are added by the syntax highlighting live. This is possible because the text editor is made of elements and because the graph layouts can be expressed as regular layouts. This means that we can arbitrarily combine graphs-like interfaces (and graph structures are common place in software) with typical widgets.

text:
>Also the ad-hoc development tools idea is very interesting, especially because IDEs provide some “canned” queries on your system but in such a locked-in manner that it makes them marginally useless

We call this property moldability, and it is a central property of our environment. The interesting thing is that it exercises the way you build the system in an orthogonal manner with respect to just testing / functionality.

The other thing about it is that these tools can make the internals of systems explainable in ways that other humans can relate to very quickly. This has all sorts of implications. For example, when doing domain-driven design we only draw a picture on the whiteboard when the system does not exist. Once the system exists, it is its responsibility to draw it. This then increases greatly the ubiquitousness of the language.

elements.text: Also the ad-hoc development tools idea is very interesting, especially because IDEs provide some “canned” queries on your system but in such a locked-in manner that it makes them marginally useless

We call this property moldability, and it is a central property of our environment. The interesting thing is that it exercises the way you build the system in an orthogonal manner with respect to just testing / functionality.

The other thing about it is that these tools can make the internals of systems explainable in ways that other humans can relate to very quickly. This has all sorts of implications. For example, when doing domain-driven design we only draw a picture on the whiteboard when the system does not exist. Once the system exists, it is its responsibility to draw it. This then increases greatly the ubiquitousness of the language.

text: I think moldability to some extent is about readability/comprehension (and you mention both in the podcast). I was motivated by the same uses to explore the datalog-query-driven comprehension of codebases

elements.text: I think moldability to some extent is about readability/comprehension (and you mention both in the podcast). I was motivated by the same uses to explore the datalog-query-driven comprehension of codebases

text: but you’ve taken this much much further because you already have all the visual aspects covered (or at least you have very good tools to make any visuals you can imagine)

text: sorry for linking you to unfinished thoughts (it literally cuts mid-sentence!), but I think storytelling is very central to software development (and from what I’ve heard you agree!): <https://github.com/stathissideris/positano/blob/master/doc/design.md>

elements.text: sorry for linking you to unfinished thoughts (it literally cuts mid-sentence!), but I think storytelling is very central to software development (and from what I’ve heard you agree!):

text: I think that is an important area, but I believe our field needs much more basic tools first. We first need to be able to tell the stories we already know much faster. For example, integration does not relate only to developers, but also to all other stakeholders. That's why we have a reasonably advanced live documenting engine where you can put together a narrative and just ship to a manager and that manager will read it in the same IDE.

elements.text: I think that is an important area, but I believe our field needs much more basic tools first. We first need to be able to tell the stories we already know much faster. For example, integration does not relate only to developers, but also to all other stakeholders. That's why we have a reasonably advanced live documenting engine where you can put together a narrative and just ship to a manager and that manager will read it in the same IDE.

text: indeed! we actually see GT as a storytelling platform :slightly_smiling_face:

text: As part of the development of Glamorous Toolkit, we also developed example-driven development, a technique that replaces TDD and that makes examples (like tests) also be documentation units. I put together a little writeup about it and I'd be interested in feedback: <https://medium.com/feenk/an-example-of-example-driven-development-4dea0d995920>
